title: 105_s448
content: The Act titled "Local Government Interstate Waste Control Act" addresses the interstate transportation and disposal of municipal solid waste under the Solid Waste Disposal Act. It introduces a new section, SEC. 4011, to regulate this aspect. The "Local Government Interstate Waste Control Act" prohibits out-of-state municipal solid waste disposal at landfills or incinerators without local government authorization. Authorization must be granted formally, recorded in writing, and final. Prior to granting authorization for out-of-state municipal solid waste disposal, affected local governments must require facility owners to provide detailed information about the facility and waste quantities. Prior to granting authorization for out-of-state municipal solid waste disposal, affected local governments must require facility owners to provide detailed information about the facility and waste quantities, including volume, facility site map, environmental characteristics, and buffer zones. The curr_chunk discusses environmental controls for a facility, including runon or runoff management, air pollution control devices, methane monitoring, landfill covers, and waste residuals management. It also includes site access controls. The curr_chunk provides details on site access controls, roadway improvements, required permits, personnel requirements, and state law compliance for a facility. The curr_chunk details state law requirements for environmental violations, gifts and contributions, and compliance with solid waste management plans by the owner or operator. Prior to granting authorization for out-of-State municipal solid waste, an affected local government must notify the Governor, adjoining local governments, and any adjoining Indian tribes. This notification includes publishing a notice in a newspaper at least 30 days before a hearing. The local government must notify the Governor, adjoining local governments, and any adjoining Indian tribes of an authorization granted for out-of-State municipal solid waste. This includes providing an opportunity for public comment and holding at least one public hearing. Landfills and incinerators in operation or under construction are exempt from this requirement. The operator must have documented authorization from the local government to accept out-of-State municipal solid waste and comply with all relevant laws and standards for landfill operation. The operator must comply with monitoring, financial assurance, and corrective action requirements for closure and post-closure care. Documentation of municipal solid waste shipments must be provided to the Governor. Governors have the authority to restrict out-of-state municipal solid waste disposal at landfills. Governors have the authority to limit out-of-state municipal solid waste disposal at landfills in response to requests from local governments and solid waste planning units. Governors can restrict out-of-state municipal solid waste disposal at landfills upon request from local governments and solid waste planning units. Prior to making a request, the local government must provide public notice and allow for comments on the proposal. Governors can restrict out-of-state municipal solid waste disposal at landfills upon request from local governments and solid waste planning units. The Governor must respond consistently without discrimination based on landfill or waste origin. The Governor's authority is limited by state law compliance. The section clarifies that actions must comply with State law and existing disposal contracts. It does not affect agreements in effect before enactment, and landfill operators must allow public inspection of contracts in the local community. The section requires landfill operators to make contracts for out-of-State waste disposal available for public inspection in the local community. States can choose to be exempt from this requirement by notifying the Administrator. The section allows States to be exempt from the requirement for landfill operators to make out-of-State waste disposal contracts available for public inspection by notifying the Administrator. The term 'affected local government' refers to elected officials with primary jurisdiction over the land where the landfill or incinerator is located. The curr_chunk discusses terms related to solid waste management, including the definition of municipal solid waste and host agreements between landfill operators and local governments. The curr_chunk defines municipal solid waste as waste generated by the general public or from residential, commercial, institutional, or industrial sources, consisting of various combustible and noncombustible materials. Exclusions include hazardous waste, industrial waste, medical waste, and recyclable materials separated from waste destined for disposal. The curr_chunk further defines terms related to waste management, including out-of-state municipal solid waste and owner or operator of landfills or incinerators. The curr_chunk amends the Solid Waste Disposal Act by specifying who is considered the owner or operator of a landfill or incinerator. The curr_chunk introduces regulations for interstate transportation and disposal of municipal solid waste under Sec. 4011.
